Authors:
Sem Samuel Surja, Robiatul Adawiyah, Jos Houbraken, Anna
Rozaliyani, Ridhawati Sjam, Evy Yunihastuti, Retno Wahyuningsih
Title:
Talaromyces atroroseus and Talaromyces marneffei isolated
from patients with and without HIV infection: report from Indonesia
Keywords:
Talaromyces atroroseus, Talaromyces marneffei, Indonesia,
ITS, BenA
Abstract:
Some species in genus Talaromyces are important to human
and can cause mycosis. Talaromyces marneffei is the most well-known
mycosis-causing species, but there are other species reported; however,
their role as a pathogen is questionable. Currently, there are five
recorded talaromycosis cases suspectedly coming from Indonesia, and most
of these cases were diagnosed in tourists who visited Indonesia. In this
study, we performed a molecular study on 10 suspected Talaromyces
marneffei isolates: eight clinical isolates and two isolates from rat. A
molecular identification was performed by sequencing the internal
transcribed spacer (ITS) regions and a part of the beta-tubulin (BenA)
gene. Nine isolates were identified as Talaromyces atroroseus (including
the isolates from rat) and one as T. marneffei. All but one T.
atroroseus isolates investigated in this study had identical ITS and
BenA sequences and this indicates an animal reservoir and zoonotic
transmission of this species. Phylogenetic analysis showed that our T.
atroroseus isolates cluster with T. atroroseus strains that were
recommended to be used for the production of food grade pigments. Only
one isolate was identified as T. marneffei, and based our results, T.
atroroseus might be the main etiologic agent of talaromycosis in
Jakarta. Talaromyces atroroseus should also be considered as a cause of
talaromycosis in humans and this study shows the need for a larger
epidemiological study to assess Talaromyces spp. endemicity in
Indonesia.
